page.title: 16Strensham Court Estate
page.content: The estate of Strensham Court now exist's mainly as a piece of natural wood. The ground covers an area of approx 15 acres. There are a large number of trees yew, holly, sycamore, horse water and sweet chestnut. The remains of the old house are still to be seen. The stable block is about to be rebuilt to make twelve dwellings in the style of a mews. These buildings are listed as grade two. The plants and animals that are to be found are varied and some are quite rare. There is a very active badger set, lots of foxes and rabbits, the bird population is also very prolific ranging from birds of prey, owls and wood peckers, nightingales, jays, to the more common birds. Views of a large man made lake, used for Otter hunting, now lie on private land. An ice house still remains from the past.
